page.title: 13Morwenstow - Flora
page.content: Morwenstow is a wonderful area for wild flowers, hellebore, primroses, celandines, daffodils, violets, blue- bells, campions, foxgloves, honey- suckle, several kinds of vetches, clovers, hawkbits, trefoils, cranes- bills and the hogweeds, cliff squill, daisies, thrift, heather, thyme and scabious. The rare ones are tansy and striated cranesbill. With the spraying of cornfields it's hard now to find wild pansy, poppy, fumitory or chamomile. Weedkiller used by the Council is destroying quite a lot of flowers and many hedges are gone too. Miss Amy Tape(1879-1968) loved flowers and planted bulbs and roots to help to beautify the landscape. The daffodils carpeting the churchyard and clumps of spring flowers in the hedgerows are mainly the result of her efforts.
